item.title: Raglan Castle - Wikipedia
item.description: Raglan Castle (Welsh: Castell Rhaglan) is a late medieval castle located just north of the village of Raglan in the county of Monmouthshire in south east Wales.

item.title: Raglan Castle - Cadw
item.description: The unmistakable silhouette of Raglan crowning a ridge amid glorious countryside is the grandest castle ever built by Welshmen. We can thank Sir William ap Thomas, the ‘blue knight of Gwent’, for the moated Great Tower of 1435 that still dominates this mighty fortress-palace.

item.title: Raglan Castle: Grand Welsh Ruins And Forgotten Majesty
item.description: Raglan has a rather checkered history – it started life, in late Medieval times, as a real fortified castle. However, being built during a peaceful period in the English/Welsh border wars, it didn’t see much military action. As a result, it evolved into a breathtakingly beautiful Tudor manor-house.

item.title: Raglan Castle: A Historic Welsh Fortress and Noble Residence
item.description: Raglan Castle, near the village of Raglan in southeast Wales, offers a glimpse into medieval and Renaissance noble life through its layered history and well-preserved ruins. It reflects centuries of architectural evolution, regional power shifts, and the blend of defense with residential grandeur.

item.title: Raglan Castle - Castles and Legends
item.description: Explore Raglan Castle in Monmouthshire - a 15th-century fortress built by Sir William ap Thomas. Discover its moated Great Tower, rich history, and scenic views.

item.title: Raglan Castle - Great Castles
item.description: Raglan Castle is one of the last true castles to be built in Wales. Its construction began in the 1430s by Sir William ap Thomas, the Blue Knight of Gwent, who fought at the Battle of Agincourt with King Henry V in 1415.
